blog.name: dr-archeville
blog.title: Doktor Archeville's Laboratory
blog.description:
Hi!  I am a fat 40-something white introvert in NC.  I worked in the NCSU Libraries for 13 years, then was an insurance agent working with Aflac (quack!) for about 9 months, and currently work as a substitute teacher in Roxboro & a repairer/maintainer of sewing machines out of my home.
My preferred pronouns are he/him/his; my preferred nicknames are Doc or Dok, or Science Squid (or Jon).

I am a fan of... things.  So many things.
* Comics (DC Comics, Marvel Comics)
* Tabletop RPGs (Dungeons & Dragons/D&D/DnD, Eclipse Phase, GURPS, Pathfinder, Shadowrun, World of Darkness) (My OCs, my games)
* Video Games (Elder Scrolls series, Fallout series, Minecraft)
* Podcasts (Binging with Babish, Critical Role)
* Webcomics (Order of the Stick, Oglaf, SMBC, Schlock Mercenary, xkcd)
* Geek Culture /  Geek Life /  Misc. Geekery (including memes)

Basically, if it's got cosplay, fantasy, horror (esp. body horror and zombies), science (or SCIENCE!) & sci-fi, steampunk, or superheroes (or supervillains), I'll probably love it.

I also try to keep up with actual science and technology, especially body modification and transhumanism.
I also blog about libraries and library- & librarian-related things (including books), in part because I'd worked in a library for thirteen years, and about education (especially education in NC and education in America) due to my work in academic libraries and as a substitute teacher.  And about language and linguistics, as those fascinate me.
Also about jobs and job hunting, since I've been unemployed or underemployed for an uncomfortably long time, and we could all use a little help there.
I also enjoy cooking (and food), which is a type of science.  Here are some recipes I've collected.

This being the internet, I also reblog posts with cute animals.  I'm especially fond of bats.  And squid, cuttlefish, and other cephalopods. While I'm listing animals, I may as well provide a link to my cat posts.  It is the internet, so there are a lot of them.

I'm a big fan of/believer in people being themselves, and of consenting adults being able to do whatever they want however they want with whoever they want, no matter what others think.  (I.e., body positivity, sex positivity).  I try to keep this blog SFW -- the only porn I'll be posting here are food porn and technology porn -- but I do sometimes talk about sex (esp. sex education) and burlesque (there are some great burly troupes in the Triangle & Triad area).

I struggle with mild depression and anxiety issues, so sometimes my blog may get a bit maudlin.  But I also try to give advice on dealing with those, too.
-----------------------
Things I've Liked (Note: May contain some NSFW posts)
My Tumblr Crushes
My personal blargings
About Me / It Me
Getting To Know Me
My TMI Tuesday blargings
My Feels

Conventions!
* Animazement
* ConCarolinas
* ConTemporal
* Cosplay America
* Dragon*Con / Dragon Con

My Face
My Facebook
Art-related blargings
Music-related blargings
Most Fridays nights I’m at the Retro Film shows at the the Carolina Theatre in Durham.  Come join me!

summary: Vex & Vax sweet life in Exandria - Messuaa - Critical Role (Web Series) [Archive of Our Own]
title: Vex & Vax sweet life in Exandria - Messuaa - Critical Role (Web Series) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
Chapters: 3/?
Fandom: Critical Role (Web Series)
Rating: Not Rated
Warnings: No Archive Warnings Apply
Relationships: Percival “Percy” Fredrickstein Von Musel Klossowski de Rolo III/Vex'ahlia, Vax'ildan & Vex'ahlia (Critical Role), Keyleth/Vax'ildan (Critical Role), Shaun Gilmore/Vax'ildan
Characters: Vax'ildan (Critical Role), Vex'ahlia (Critical Role), Percival “Percy” Fredrickstein Von Musel Klossowski de Rolo III, Keyleth (Critical Role), Scanlan Shorthalt, Pike Trickfoot, Grog Strongjaw, Shaun Gilmore
Additional Tags: tags will be updated along with updates bc i have nothing planned we die like men, Crack fic I guess, idk how to tag, Sibling Bonding, twin life, One Shot fics, Humor, really just me projecting my twin stores onto my fav pair of half elven twins, Yes the title is a zack and cody reference
Summary:

Small ficlets that are really just own experiences as a twin but starring our fav half elven rogue and ranger

General theme, age and such will be written at the start of each chapter and feel free to hmu with prompts!
Not ive never written for CR and it might be OCC but i live for the twin fluff so read it or dont ill get a kick out of writing it down.

Ill add characters, ships and tags as i add more chapters.

i dont even watcg crit role but i did watch that moment
body:
top 3 dnd podcast game breakers *SPOILERS*

3. immediately guessing which party member had been possessed by brian murphy’s witch in naddpod, ending her game in one question

2. capsizing matt mercer’s ship in critical role, completely invalidating his elaborate sea-based combat sequence

1. anthony burch describing his combat system for the fight pit in dungeons and daddies, immediately followed by all four dads stripping nude and forcing the lord of chaos to reveal that he is, in fact, two boys in a trench coat

summary: Sam brought the wrong lesson from Scanlan to Nott.
body:
Sam brought the wrong lesson from Scanlan to Nott.

He seems to have carried over “I can talk people into things”. No you can’t dude, you have -3 to Charisma

He should have learned “Use the magic hand for EVERYthing”. Different magic hand, but it still applies.

He’s still a marvelous RP-er, but he needs to stop being the mouthpiece.

blog.name: thunderdice
blog.title: Thunderdice
blog.description:
Roleplaying games and Events in Edinburgh, come and say hi ! 

https://www.thunderdices.com/

body:
DM rules

Saw a post this morning about someone retelling how their Dm fed them, and only asked for a PC backstory in return. It actually made me think about “as a DM, what do I expect from my player?”.


Background - What I describe below very much depends on the style of gaming you co-established with your players. I am here only describing my experience as someone who DMs complex heavy RP and homebrew campaigns.


As a DM, i take care of the “in-game”. You sit at my table, i will take you on this journey inside the world I’ve built. And this includes making sure that you are in prime condition to be creative and to have a great time playing. This means that I will feed you, water you, look out to see if I I see you becoming too tired so we can have a break, and watch for if at any point my story makes you uncomfortable.I will spend at least 2 hours preparing our session to make it a seamless moment for you.


But the other side of this contract (and something that I will verbally tell you at our first session to get consent), is that I have 3 rules for you:


1. Build your backstory, and answer any key questions about your character I have (worst fear, etc.). This will allow me to tailor this adventure to this specific group, and it will allow me to “build the stakes” from an emotional standpoint for you.

Remember that necromencer ? Yeah he’s not just another undead lover. He’s the brother you’ve been on the lookout for the entire campaign. And when he died, to try to stay alive to reunite with you, well… he might have needed to do 1 or two unsavoury things.


2. Re-read the notes you took last time we played, before we start this session.

You are an adult adventurer and I expect you to take 10mn to get back into the story I spent a long time building. You forget a key plot point? Ooooh I will remind you of it, but you will need to work for it. In each campaign I run, i have my adventurers find in the first sessions they handle a “prayer blade”. The party must choose a player who will stab himself with it. The prayer blade does not give direct damage but upon the roll of a d20 gives:

1 - a false information

2-10 : 1d8 damage until level 10, then 2d10 damage,and the key piece of background forgotten by the players. I like to get creative with how the damage manifests. Paralysed limb? Loss of a sense? Blade bleeding poison? Ho ho ho so much fun.

10-18 : a loss of luck represented by a disadvantage on an attack roll during the next encounter, and the key piece of background forgotten by the players

19: the player forgets a minor detail about someone very important to them, and the key piece of background forgotten by the players. And this can be positive (I had this PC who hated his father. He used to beat him relentlessly and I would always describe the memories of him calling my PC “useless”. Well now, the Pc can’t quite remember how his father used to call him)… or negative (romance between NPC and PC. He waxes poetry about her eyes. And suddenly can’t remember what her eyes look like). Negative or positive is decided by the toss of a coin by the player.

20 - the information is given for free, with a bonus for the trouble caused.


3. Give it your best in the style of play we agreed on, have fun and communicate!

My last rule is both for my player and myself. If something goes wrong, if you seem down or uninvolved, tell me why! I’ll be able to adapt my style to try to cheer you up/leave you alone (as you prefer). And I will also not spend hours fretting about what I did wrong.

You might have noticed the provision “in the style of play we agreed on”. I build my campaigns differently depending on what style we agreed (fun friend hangout, horror survival, deep political RP, etc. More on the topic yall on tumblr if you want). So I always ask my players to respect the spirit of the session. If I spent 6 showers practicing an accent and posture because your characters were going to RP for their lives with a mad lord, please avoid using that moment to go cat pictures sharing (I sooo want to see them, your cat is absurdly adorable, but later).

2. Re-read the notes you took last time we played, before we start this session.

You are an adult adventurer and I expect you to take 10mn to get back into the story I spent a long time building. You forget a key plot point? Ooooh I will remind you of it, but you will need to work for it. In each campaign I run, i have my adventurers find in the first sessions they handle a “prayer blade”. The party must choose a player who will stab himself with it. The prayer blade does not give direct damage but upon the roll of a d20 gives:

1 - a false information

2-10 : 1d8 damage until level 10, then 2d10 damage,and the key piece of background forgotten by the players. I like to get creative with how the damage manifests. Paralysed limb? Loss of a sense? Blade bleeding poison? Ho ho ho so much fun.

10-18 : a loss of luck represented by a disadvantage on an attack roll during the next encounter, and the key piece of background forgotten by the players

19: the player forgets a minor detail about someone very important to them, and the key piece of background forgotten by the players. And this can be positive (I had this PC who hated his father. He used to beat him relentlessly and I would always describe the memories of him calling my PC “useless”. Well now, the Pc can’t quite remember how his father used to call him)… or negative (romance between NPC and PC. He waxes poetry about her eyes. And suddenly can’t remember what her eyes look like). Negative or positive is decided by the toss of a coin by the player.

20 - the information is given for free, with a bonus for the trouble caused.


3. Give it your best in the style of play we agreed on, have fun and communicate!

My last rule is both for my player and myself. If something goes wrong, if you seem down or uninvolved, tell me why! I’ll be able to adapt my style to try to cheer you up/leave you alone (as you prefer). And I will also not spend hours fretting about what I did wrong.

You might have noticed the provision “in the style of play we agreed on”. I build my campaigns differently depending on what style we agreed (fun friend hangout, horror survival, deep political RP, etc. More on the topic yall on tumblr if you want). So I always ask my players to respect the spirit of the session. If I spent 6 showers practicing an accent and posture because your characters were going to RP for their lives with a mad lord, please avoid using that moment to go cat pictures sharing (I sooo want to see them, your cat is absurdly adorable, but later).

trail.content_raw:
DM rules

Saw a post this morning about someone retelling how their Dm fed them, and only asked for a PC backstory in return. It actually made me think about “as a DM, what do I expect from my player?”.


Background - What I describe below very much depends on the style of gaming you co-established with your players. I am here only describing my experience as someone who DMs complex heavy RP and homebrew campaigns.


As a DM, i take care of the “in-game”. You sit at my table, i will take you on this journey inside the world I’ve built. And this includes making sure that you are in prime condition to be creative and to have a great time playing. This means that I will feed you, water you, look out to see if I I see you becoming too tired so we can have a break, and watch for if at any point my story makes you uncomfortable.I will spend at least 2 hours preparing our session to make it a seamless moment for you.


But the other side of this contract (and something that I will verbally tell you at our first session to get consent), is that I have 3 rules for you:


1. Build your backstory, and answer any key questions about your character I have (worst fear, etc.). This will allow me to tailor this adventure to this specific group, and it will allow me to “build the stakes” from an emotional standpoint for you.

Remember that necromencer ? Yeah he’s not just another undead lover. He’s the brother you’ve been on the lookout for the entire campaign. And when he died, to try to stay alive to reunite with you, well… he might have needed to do 1 or two unsavoury things.


2. Re-read the notes you took last time we played, before we start this session.

You are an adult adventurer and I expect you to take 10mn to get back into the story I spent a long time building. You forget a key plot point? Ooooh I will remind you of it, but you will need to work for it. In each campaign I run, i have my adventurers find in the first sessions they handle a “prayer blade”. The party must choose a player who will stab himself with it. The prayer blade does not give direct damage but upon the roll of a d20 gives:

1 - a false information

2-10 : 1d8 damage until level 10, then 2d10 damage,and the key piece of background forgotten by the players. I like to get creative with how the damage manifests. Paralysed limb? Loss of a sense? Blade bleeding poison? Ho ho ho so much fun.

10-18 : a loss of luck represented by a disadvantage on an attack roll during the next encounter, and the key piece of background forgotten by the players

19: the player forgets a minor detail about someone very important to them, and the key piece of background forgotten by the players. And this can be positive (I had this PC who hated his father. He used to beat him relentlessly and I would always describe the memories of him calling my PC “useless”. Well now, the Pc can’t quite remember how his father used to call him)… or negative (romance between NPC and PC. He waxes poetry about her eyes. And suddenly can’t remember what her eyes look like). Negative or positive is decided by the toss of a coin by the player.

20 - the information is given for free, with a bonus for the trouble caused.


3. Give it your best in the style of play we agreed on, have fun and communicate!

My last rule is both for my player and myself. If something goes wrong, if you seem down or uninvolved, tell me why! I’ll be able to adapt my style to try to cheer you up/leave you alone (as you prefer). And I will also not spend hours fretting about what I did wrong.

You might have noticed the provision “in the style of play we agreed on”. I build my campaigns differently depending on what style we agreed (fun friend hangout, horror survival, deep political RP, etc. More on the topic yall on tumblr if you want). So I always ask my players to respect the spirit of the session. If I spent 6 showers practicing an accent and posture because your characters were going to RP for their lives with a mad lord, please avoid using that moment to go cat pictures sharing (I sooo want to see them, your cat is absurdly adorable, but later).

summary: "I believe in life. That's all I was raised to believe in - life. When you're married to death it's pretty much all you...
body:
“I believe in life. That’s all I was raised to believe in - life. When you’re married to death it’s pretty much all you have.”

-Kashaw Vesh
